He had always intended to visit him, though to the last always assuring his wife that he should not go; and till the afternoon after the morning on which she had given her account of the family, he did not receive any invitation. But, at last, on the afternoon following, he received a note from him, and an invitation to dinner for that day, which was accepted, and at half-past six Elizabeth was summoned to the dining-room. To her nice discernment and natural ability, she was as little of a simpleton as ever appeared in print; and though there might be some parts of her character which would bear improvement, yet, upon the whole, she was very lovable; and though some people might say her beauty was not regular, no one ever yet ventured to call her anything worse than rather plain. The evening altogether passed off pleasantly to the whole family. Mr. Bennet was in high spirits; the young ladies were all in high spirits; and the evening more than answered their highest expectations; for they had the pleasure of seeing their father so happy and diverted, and of hearing him say many pleasant things, which nobody else could have said so well.

Mr. Bennet's property consisted almost entirely in an estate of two thousand a year, which, unfortunately for his daughters, was entailed, in default of heirs male, on a distant relation; and their mother's fortune, though ample for her situation in life, could but ill supply the deficiency of his. Her father had been an attorney in Meryton, and had left her four thousand pounds. The village of Longbourn was only one mile from Meryton; a most convenient distance for the young ladies, who were usually tempted thither three or four times a week, to pay their duty to their aunt and to a milliner's shop just over the way. The two youngest of the family, Catherine and Lydia, were particularly frequent in these attentions; their minds were more vacant than their sisters', and when nothing better offered, a walk to Meryton was necessary to amuse their morning hours and furnish conversation for the evening; and however bare of news the country in general might be, they always contrived to learn some from their aunt. At present, indeed, they were well supplied both with news and happiness by the recent arrival of a militia regiment in the neighbourhood; it was to remain the whole winter, and Meryton was the headquarters.

Indeed, I think it is a good thing that he has a high opinion of himself, for it will make him more careful in his conduct and more anxious to maintain a good character. I am sure that Mr. Darcy is a very respectable young man, and that he will make a good husband to some lady or other, though I do not think that he will ever be induced to marry a woman who is not his equal in rank and fortune.

en_second_half: cherish a feeling of self-complacency on the score of some quality or other, real or imaginary. Vanity and pride are different things, though the words are often used synonymously. A person may be proud without being vain. Pride relates more to our opinion of ourselves; vanity to what we would have others think of us.”
en_results_raw: cherish a feeling of self-importance, which, if not checked, can lead to the most unbecoming and hurtful behavior. I daresay, we have all, at some point or another, been guilty of this fault, and have, perhaps, been taken in by our own self-conceit, only to discover, to our mortification, that we were mistaken in our own abilities or judgment. But, I must confess, that I have always found it to be a most unbecoming trait, and one that can lead to the greatest unhappiness, not only to the individual who possesses it, but also to those around them. It is a failing that can make us appear ridiculous, and can lead us to commit the most egregious errors, and yet, it is a failing that is so very hard to overcome. I have known people, who, despite their best efforts, have been unable to shake off this most unbecoming of traits, and have, as a result, been the cause of great distress to themselves and others. But, I must say, that I do believe that it is a failing that can be overcome, with great effort and determination, and that it is a most worthy endeavor to strive for humility, and to cultivate a more modest and unassuming nature.

Một người có thể cảm thấy kiêu hãnh nhưng không tỏ ra phù phiếm. Kiêu hãnh là khi ta có ý kiến về chính mình, phù phiếm là khi ta muốn người khác nghĩ về mình như thế nào.

Khi chúng ta quá tự mãn, chúng ta có thể trở nên kiêu ngạo, coi thường người khác và không sẵn sàng lắng nghe ý kiến của họ. Điều này có thể dẫn đến sự cô lập và mất đi những cơ hội quý giá.  Em cũng tin rằng kiêu hãnh có thể cản trở sự phát triển cá nhân. Khi chúng ta quá tự mãn, chúng ta có thể không sẵn sàng học hỏi và cải thiện bản thân. Chúng ta có thể nghĩ rằng mình đã biết đủ và không cần phải cố gắng hơn nữa. Điều này có thể dẫn đến sự trì trệ và không đạt được mục tiêu.  Tuy nhiên, em cũng tin rằng kiêu hãnh không phải là một khuyết điểm không thể sửa chữa. Chúng ta có thể nhận ra và vượt qua nó bằng cách tự nhận thức và cố gắng cải thiện bản thân. Chúng ta có thể học cách lắng nghe và học hỏi từ người khác, và sẵn sàng thừa nhận sai lầm của mình. Bằng cách làm như vậy, chúng ta có thể trở thành người tốt hơn và đạt được thành công trong cuộc sống.
es_first_half: ––El orgullo ––observó Mary, que se preciaba mucho de la solidez de sus reflexiones––, es un defecto muy común. Por todo lo que he leído, estoy convencida de que en realidad es muy frecuente que la naturaleza humana sea especialmente propensa a él, hay muy pocos que no abriguen un sentimiento
es_second_half: de autosuficiencia por una u otra razón, ya sea real o imaginaria. La vanidad y el orgullo son cosas distintas, aunque muchas veces se usen como sinónimos. El orgullo está relacionado con la opinión que tenemos de nosotros mismos; la vanidad, con lo que quisiéramos que los demás pensaran de nosotros.
es_results_raw: de orgullo en algún momento de sus vidas. Sin embargo, creo que hay una gran diferencia entre el orgullo que se siente por logros genuinos y el que se basa en la vanidad o la apariencia. El primero es un sentimiento noble y justificable, mientras que el segundo es un defecto que puede llevar a la persona a cometer errores y a lastimar a los demás. Me pregunto si la naturaleza humana no sería más feliz y armoniosa si pudiéramos encontrar un equilibrio entre la confianza en nosotros mismos y la humildad. ¿No sería maravilloso si pudiéramos sentir orgullo por nuestros logros sin dejar que eso nos lleve a menospreciar a los demás? Me parece que la clave está en reconocer que todos tenemos defectos y virtudes, y que la verdadera grandeza se encuentra en la capacidad de reconocer y aceptar nuestras limitaciones. De esta manera, podemos cultivar un orgullo saludable que nos permita crecer y mejorar sin dejar de ser humildes y empáticos con los demás.

She skipped along, her feet barely touching the ground, and her heart full of joy and excitement. As she walked, the trees seemed to grow taller and the path grew narrower, until she found herself at the edge of a clearing. In the center of the clearing stood an enormous tree, its trunk twisted and gnarled with age, and its branches reaching up towards the sky like giant arms. The girl felt drawn to the tree, as if it was calling to her, and she walked towards it, her curiosity getting the better of her. As she reached the base of the tree, she noticed a small door carved into the trunk, and she felt a shiver run down her spine. She hesitated for a moment, wondering if she should open the door, but her curiosity got the better of her, and she slowly turned the handle and pushed the door open.

"Perhaps that is not possible for anyone. But it has been the study of my life to avoid those weaknesses which often expose a strong understanding to ridicule." "Such as vanity and pride," said Mr. Darcy, who had been watching her countenance with great interest. "Yes, vanity is a weakness indeed. But pride—where there is a real superiority of mind, pride will be always under good regulation." Elizabeth turned away, to hide a smile. "I think I have heard you say that pride is a very common failing, that it is the general cause of the many errors committed by women in their youth." "It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife. However little known the feelings or views of such a man may be on his first entering a neighbourhood, this truth is so well fixed in the minds of the surrounding families, that he is considered the rightful property of some one or other of their daughters." "My dear Mr. Bennet," said his lady to him one day, "have you heard that Netherfield Park is let at last?" Mr. Bennet replied that he had not. "But it is," returned she; "for Mrs. Long has just been here, and she told me all about it." Mr. Bennet made no answer. "Do you not want to know who has taken it?" cried his wife impatiently. "You want to tell me, and I have no objection to hearing it." This was invitation enough. "Why, my dear, you must know, Mrs. Long says that Netherfield is taken by a young man of large fortune from the north of England; that he came down on Monday in a chaise-and-four to see the place, and was so much delighted with it that he agreed with Mr. Morris immediately; that he is to take possession before Michaelmas, and some of his servants are to be in the house by the end of next week." "What is his name?" "Bingley." "Is he married or single?" "Oh! Single, my dear, to be sure! A single man of large fortune; four or five thousand a-year. What a fine thing for our girls!" "How so? how can it affect them?" "My dear Mr. Bennet, replied his wife, "you must not expect such girls to have many offers of marriage in this neighbourhood. It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife. However little known the feelings or views of such a man may be on his first entering a neighbourhood, this truth is so well fixed in the minds of the surrounding families, that he is considered the rightful property of some one or other of their daughters. "My dear Mr. Bennet, have you heard who is coming to Netherfield? It is a single man of large fortune, and I hope he will take one of my daughters." "Is that his design in settling here?" "Design! nonsense, how can you talk so! But it is very likely that he may fall in love with one of them, and therefore you must visit him as soon as he comes." "I see no occasion for that. You and the girls may go, or you may send them by themselves, which perhaps will be still better, for as you are as handsome as any of them, Mr. Bingley may like you the best of the party." "My dear, you flatter me. I certainly _have_ had my share of beauty, but I do not pretend to be anything extraordinary now. When a woman has five grown-up daughters, she ought to give over thinking of her own beauty." "In such cases, a woman's beauty is of little consequence." en_first_half: After amusing himself some time with their curiosity, he thus explained:—“About a month ago I received this letter, and about a fortnight ago I answered it; for I thought it a case
en_second_half: of some delicacy, and requiring early attention. It is from my cousin, Mr. Collins, who, when I am dead, may turn you all out of this house as soon as he pleases.”
en_results_raw: of some importance, and one which I could not resolve on my own. The letter was from a man who claimed to have information about a matter that had been puzzling me for quite some time. He requested a meeting, and I agreed, as I was eager to learn more about what he had to say. I must admit, I was a bit skeptical at first, but as I read on, I became increasingly intrigued. He wrote of a discovery that, if true, would change everything I thought I knew about the subject. I couldn't wait to hear more, and so I agreed to meet with him at the old oak tree in the town square at midnight. I arrived early, my heart racing with anticipation, and waited for what felt like an eternity for him to arrive. And then, just as I was starting to think I had been stood up, I saw a figure emerging from the shadows. He was tall and gaunt, with piercing eyes that seemed to bore into my very soul. I felt a shiver run down my spine as he approached me, but I stood my ground, determined to learn the truth. "So, you're the one who's been writing to me," I said, trying to sound calm. He nodded, his eyes glinting in the moonlight. "I am," he replied, his voice low and gravelly. "And I have come to tell you a story that will change your life forever."

I only hope that she will not be too proud, and that she will be willing to visit us at Longbourn, and to receive our visits in return. I was sorry at the time, but I did not know the greatness of the loss I had sustained till the following autumn, when I was invited to a ball at Netherfield, and saw the lady who was to be the mistress of the house. I was so much struck with her beauty and her air of elegance, that I could hardly believe she was the daughter of a man who had made his fortune by trade. I was determined to know more of her, and I watched her with great attention during the evening. She was surrounded by a crowd of admirers, but she seemed to be enjoying herself very little. I observed that she danced but little, and that when she did, it was with a partner who was not equal to her in rank or in elegance. I thought to myself, "This is a young woman of great beauty and great pride, who is not likely to be pleased with the society of this neighbourhood." I was confirmed in this opinion by the conversation I had with her during the evening. She was polite and courteous, but I could see that she was not at her ease, and that she was anxious to get away from the crowd. I had imagined that the daughter of a man who had made his fortune by trade would be a bold, forward, and impudent girl, but she was quite the reverse. She wondered what could be the reason for such behaviour, and whether Mr. Darcy was aware of the pain he was causing. As she pondered on these thoughts, she couldn't help but feel a sense of disappointment and disillusionment with the man she had once thought so highly of. His actions seemed to be a stark contrast to the charming and agreeable person she had met at the ball, and she found herself questioning her initial impression of him. en_first_half: He shook his head. “I wish I could call her amiable. It gives me pain to speak ill of a Darcy; but she is too much like her brother,—very, very proud. As a child, she was affectionate and pleasing, and extremely fond of me; and I have
en_second_half: devoted hours and hours to her amusement. But she is nothing to me now. She is a handsome girl, about fifteen or sixteen, and, I understand, highly accomplished. Since her father’s death her home has been London, where a lady lives with her, and superintends her education.”
en_results_raw: no doubt that she was of a most affectionate disposition. But she has been so completely spoiled by her mother and her brother, that she is now absolutely unmanageable. I do not mean to say that she is not a very clever and agreeable woman, but she is so excessively proud, and so convinced of her own superiority, that she is really quite unbearable. I have seen her behave in a way that would make your blood boil, and yet she seems to think herself perfectly justified in everything she does. I am afraid she will never make a good wife, for she is far too selfish and too used to having her own way. I do not know what Mr. Darcy sees in her, unless it is her beauty, which is certainly very striking. But beauty is not everything, and I fear that he will find her a very uncomfortable companion in the end.

en_first_half: “Probably not; but Mr. Darcy can please where he chooses. He does not want abilities. He can be a conversible companion if he thinks it worth his while. Among those who are at all his equals in consequence,
en_second_half: he is a very different man from what he is to the less prosperous. His pride never deserts him; but with the rich he is liberal-minded, just, sincere, rational, honourable, and, perhaps, agreeable,—allowing something for fortune and figure.”

I am not sure that I ever saw such a mixture of pique and curiosity as Elizabeth's in this respect. She could not help watching him, and her agitation was heightened by the idea of his being so near her, and yet so little disposed to notice her. She had never seen him so desirous of being acquainted with her, and yet so little inclined to make friends with her. She was almost afraid to speak to him, and yet she could not help feeling a strong desire to know more of him. She was not sure if she liked him, but she was determined to find out. She was not going to let his pride and haughty reserve intimidate her, and she was resolved to make him talk, no matter what it took.

en_second_half: dissemble; my attentions have been too marked to be mistaken. Almost as soon as I entered the house I singled you out as the companion of my future life. But before I am run away with by my feelings on this subject, perhaps it will be advisable for me to state my reasons for marrying—and, moreover, for coming into Hertfordshire with the design of selecting a wife, as I certainly did.”

As I was saying, I have the utmost pleasure in informing you that I have obtained your mother's consent to pay my addresses to you, and I must confess that I am eager to make you happy. I daresay you are not insensible to the advantages of a union between us, and I flatter myself that you will not find me an unamiable companion. My situation in life, my connections, and my fortune, are all such as to secure your comfort and happiness, and I trust that you will not refuse the offer I make you. I am aware that I may seem precipitate in my proposal, but I assure you that my feelings are sincere, and that I am willing to wait for your answer, though I must confess that I am not without hope that it will be favorable. I have long admired your beauty, your accomplishments, and your character, and I am convinced that we should be happy together. I shall be delighted to call on you tomorrow, and to have the pleasure of a more private conversation with you, when I shall be able to explain myself more fully, and to answer any questions you may have to ask. Until then, I remain, with the utmost respect and esteem, your devoted admirer.

I had hoped that, after the encouragement I had received from your family, I might have been met with a more favourable reception. I confess, I was not prepared for such a decided rejection. I had flattered myself that, at least, you would have given me some reason for your refusal, or that you would have allowed me to hope that, in time, you might see me in a more favourable light. But I am not one to be easily discouraged, and I must own that I am not yet willing to give up all hope. I shall endeavour to convince you, by my future conduct, that I am not unworthy of your esteem, and that I am truly attached to you. I shall not trouble you with any further professions now, but I must beg of you to believe that my intentions are sincere, and that I shall always be happy to be of service to you, whether you accept my offer or not.

en_first_half: “You must give me leave to flatter myself, my dear cousin, that your refusal of my addresses are merely words of course. My reasons for believing it are briefly these:—It does not appear to me that my hand is unworthy your acceptance, or that the establishment I can offer would be any other than highly desirable. My situation in life, my connections with the family of De Bourgh, and my relationship to your own, are circumstances highly in my favour; and you should take it
en_second_half: into further consideration that, in spite of your manifold attractions, it is by no means certain that another offer of marriage may ever be made you. Your portion is unhappily so small, that it will in all likelihood undo the effects of your loveliness and amiable qualifications. As I must, therefore, conclude that you are not serious in your rejection of me, I shall choose to attribute it to your wish of increasing my love by suspense, according to the usual practice of elegant females.”
en_results_raw: into consideration, when you are deciding on the answer to give. But, as I was saying, my dear cousin, I have other reasons for believing that your refusal is merely a matter of form. I have observed the way you have looked at me during our conversations, and I am convinced that you do not regard me with indifference. I have seen a spark in your eye, a certain... I know not what, that tells me that you are not entirely averse to my suit. And then, of course, there is the fact that you have not forbidden me to continue my attentions. If you had truly wished me to desist, you would have said so by now. No, I am convinced that you are merely playing a game, a game of coyness and reserve, and that you will eventually come to see the sense in accepting my proposal. I must confess, my dear cousin, that I am not a man to be easily deterred. I am determined to win your hand, and I shall not rest until I have done so. I shall continue to pay my addresses to you, and I shall not be put off by any show of reluctance on your part. I am convinced that, in the end, you will see that I am the only man who can make you truly happy, and that you will accept my proposal with gratitude. And so, my dear cousin, I shall continue to hope, and to press my suit with all the ardour at my command.
vi_first_half: - Cô em ạ, cô phải cho tôi tự mãn rằng sự khước từ của cô chỉ là những lời lẽ tất nhiên. Những lý do để tôi tin điều ấy là ngắn gọn thế này. Không có vẻ gì là bản thân tôi không đáng được cô chấp nhận, hoặc địa vị của tôi không đủ cao. Hoàn cảnh của tôi, những kết giao với gia đình De Bourgh, mối quan hệ với gia đình cô, đều là những hoàn cảnh vô cùng thuận lợi cho tôi; và cô nên suy xét thêm rằng mặc
vi_second_half: dù cô có những hấp dẫn về nhiều mặt, vẫn không chắc rằng cô sẽ nhận được một lời cầu hôn khác. Phần sự sản của cô không may là quá nhỏ nên vẻ kiều diễm của cô và những đức tính khả ái khác có thể mất tác dụng. Vì tôi đã phải kết luận rằng cô không nghiêm túc khi từ chối tôi, tôi chỉ có cách tin rằng cô muốn tình yêu của tôi sâu đậm hơn trong tình trạng hồi hộp, theo như cung cách thường thấy của những phụ nữ tao nhã.
vi_results_raw: dù tôi không phải là người đàn ông giàu có nhất, nhưng tôi vẫn có đủ khả năng để cung cấp cho cô một cuộc sống sung túc và hạnh phúc. Tôi không có bất kỳ hành vi xấu nào trong quá khứ, và tôi luôn cố gắng trở thành một người tốt. Tôi cũng không có bất kỳ đối thủ nào trong việc theo đuổi cô, vì vậy tôi không có lý do gì để lo lắng về việc mình sẽ bị từ chối.  Tôi biết rằng cô có thể đang nghĩ về những điều khác, nhưng tôi hy vọng cô sẽ xem xét lại những điều tôi đã nói. Tôi không muốn cô nghĩ rằng tôi đang cố gắng ép buộc cô phải chấp nhận tôi, nhưng tôi chỉ muốn cô biết rằng tôi thực sự yêu cô và muốn được ở bên cạnh cô. Tôi sẽ không bao giờ quên được những khoảnh khắc chúng ta đã chia sẻ, và tôi hy vọng rằng một ngày nào đó, chúng ta sẽ có thể cùng nhau xây dựng một tương lai hạnh phúc.  Tôi biết rằng tôi có thể không phải là người đàn ông hoàn hảo, nhưng tôi hứa sẽ luôn cố gắng làm cho cô hạnh phúc. Tôi sẽ luôn ở bên cạnh cô, lắng nghe cô, và hỗ trợ cô trong mọi hoàn cảnh. Tôi sẽ không bao giờ bỏ rơi cô, và tôi sẽ luôn yêu cô với tất cả trái tim mình.  Tôi hy vọng rằng cô sẽ xem xét lại những điều tôi đã nói, và sẽ cho tôi cơ hội để chứng minh tình yêu của mình. Tôi sẽ không bao giờ quên được cảm giác khi chúng ta lần đầu tiên gặp nhau, và tôi hy vọng rằng một ngày nào đó, chúng ta sẽ có thể cùng nhau tạo ra những ký ức đẹp đẽ khác. Tôi yêu cô, và tôi sẽ luôn yêu cô, cho dù cô có chấp nhận tôi hay không.
es_first_half: ––Debe dejar que presuma, mi querida prima, que su rechazó ha sido sólo de boquilla. Las razones que tengo para creerlo, son las siguientes: no creo que mi mano no merezca ser aceptada por usted ni que la posición que le ofrezco deje de ser altamente apetecible. Mi situación en la vida, mi relación con la familia de Bourgh y mi parentesco con usted son circunstancias importantes en mi favor. Considere,
es_second_half: además, que a pesar de sus muchos atractivos, no es seguro que reciba otra proposición de matrimonio. Su fortuna es tan escasa que anulará, por desgracia, los efectos de su belleza y buenas cualidades. Así pues, como no puedo deducir de todo esto que haya procedido sinceramente al rechazarme, optaré por atribuirlo a su deseo de acrecentar mi amor con el suspense, de acuerdo con la práctica acostumbrada en las mujeres elegantes.
es_results_raw: que mi fortuna es considerable, que mi casa es cómoda y que mi carácter, aunque no perfecto, no es del todo desagradable. ¿Por qué, entonces, rechazar mi proposición? ¿Es posible que haya algún otro hombre que le interese? ¿O es que simplemente no está dispuesta a casarse? Si es así, le ruego que me explique sus razones, que me dé la oportunidad de entender su punto de vista. Estoy dispuesto a escucharla, a considerar sus argumentos y a respetar su decisión, aunque me duela admitirlo. Pero, por favor, no me deje en la incertidumbre. Dígame la verdad, prima mía. ¿Qué hay detrás de su rechazo? ¿Es algo que pueda cambiar, algo que pueda hacer para ganarme su afecto? Estoy dispuesto a hacer cualquier cosa, a cambiar cualquier aspecto de mi personalidad o de mi vida, con tal de merecer su amor y su respeto. ¿Es eso demasiado pedir? ¿O es que simplemente no soy digno de su consideración? Dígame, prima mía, dígame la verdad.

en_first_half: “I found,” said he, “as the time drew near, that I had better not meet Mr. Darcy;—that to be in the same room, the same
en_second_half: party with him for so many hours together, might be more than I could bear, and that scenes might arise unpleasant to more than myself.”
en_results_raw: house with him for so many hours together, would be more than I could bear; and before I had any right to give a denial. This will be a trial to be sure; but after a little acquaintance with him I shall imagine his manners too marked, too decided, to be mistaken. I have not the smallest doubt of their receiving us with civility, even with affection; but I am by no means assured of their liking us. They may be of a very different sort from what I have been used to, and I do not think I should be at all in my element. I am not quite certain that I should be able to keep my countenance, and I know I should be miserable if I were to meet him again. I am not at all afraid of being long unemployed; there are many things that I can do, and I shall always have something to occupy me; but I must confess, that I do not look forward to this visit with any great degree of pleasure. I am afraid I shall find it very dull, and I do not think I shall be able to make myself agreeable. I shall endeavour to do my best, but I am not sanguine of success. I am rather inclined to think that I shall be a restraint on the family, and that they will be glad when I am gone. I do not think I shall be able to join in their amusements, and I am afraid I shall be a great deal in the way. I shall try to be as little troublesome as possible, but I fear I shall not be able to avoid being a burden to them. I am not at all sure that I shall be able to make myself at home, and I am afraid I shall feel very uncomfortable. I shall do my best to be agreeable, but I am not very hopeful of being able to succeed.

en_first_half: “‘When my brother left us yesterday, he imagined that the business which took him to London might be concluded in three or four days; but as we are certain it cannot be so, and at the same time convinced that when Charles gets to town he will be in no hurry to leave it again, we have determined on following him thither, that he may not be obliged to spend his vacant hours in a comfortless

I need something more substantial, more vivid, and more precise to grasp the intensity of his emotions. Was he the type of person who would write sonnets and poetry, or was he more of a romantic who would surprise his loved one with grand gestures? Perhaps he was the quiet and brooding type, with a deep passion that simmered just below the surface. Whatever the case, I was determined to uncover the truth behind his enigmatic words, to peel back the layers and reveal the depths of his feelings.

Tình yêu không chỉ là những cảm xúc mạnh mẽ, mà còn là sự cam kết, sự hy sinh, và sự hiểu biết sâu sắc về đối phương. Nó đòi hỏi sự trưởng thành, sự kiên nhẫn, và sự tự giác. Vì vậy, khi nói về tình yêu, chúng ta cần phải có sự cẩn trọng và chính xác trong cách sử dụng ngôn từ, để tránh gây ra sự hiểu lầm và để thể hiện được bản chất thực sự của tình yêu.

Seriously, I would have you be on your guard. Do not involve yourself, or endeavour to involve him, in an affection which the want of fortune would make so very imprudent. I have nothing to say against him: he
en_second_half: is a most interesting young man; and if he had the fortune he ought to have, I should think you could not do better. But as it is—you must not let your fancy run away with you. en_results_raw: is a gentleman-like, pleasant young man, I am sure, and I know you think him so. But with your inferior family connections, and his having no immediate prospect of employment or connections, it is not a match that I should like to see you make. I know that you are not romantic, Lizzy, and that you will not imagine that a man is in love with you just because he is attentive and agreeable. But still, I wish you to be careful. You are young, and you have a lively disposition, and it would be a great pity if you were to throw yourself away on a man who, though he may be very agreeable, is not in a situation to support you in the manner to which you have been accustomed. I know that your father is not a man of large fortune, but still, he has a comfortable income, and you have been brought up in a way that would make it difficult for you to adapt to a very different style of living. I only want what is best for you, Lizzy, and I hope you will take my advice and be cautious in your dealings with this young man.

es_second_half: tengo que decir contra él; es un muchacho muy interesante, y si tuviera la posición que debería tener, me parecería inmejorable. Pero tal y como están las cosas, no puedes cegarte. en_first_half: When they left the high road for the lane to Hunsford, every eye was in search of the Parsonage, and every turning expected to bring it
en_second_half: in view. The paling of Rosings park was their boundary on one side. Elizabeth smiled at the recollection of all that she had heard of its inhabitants.
en_results_raw: in view. The palings of Rosings Park was their boundary on one side. Elizabeth smiled at the recollection of all that she had heard of its inhabitants. At length the Parsonage was discernible. The garden sloping to the road, the house standing in it, the green pales and the laurel hedge, everything declared they were arriving. This was a stroke of civility for which she was quite unprepared; and she began to wonder at the sort of welcome she was likely to meet with. As she raised her eyes to the house, she saw her sister exceedingly well pleased, and in a moment afterwards heard Kitty express her admiration of its size and furniture, on a scale larger than she had ever seen in a private house before. 'What a fine old-fashioned place!' said she. 'Is it not a beautiful day? I think the front is very pretty.' Elizabeth was delighted. She had never seen a place for which nature had done more, or where natural beauty had been so little counteracted by an awkward taste. They were all of them warm in their admiration; and at that moment she knew the efforts of her sister would be crowned with success. As they walked towards the house, Elizabeth, struck by the manner of their being received, began to entertain a suspicion that Mr. Bingley's sisters were not of very amiable disposition. She watched them attentively as they walked, and overheard the various remarks of the two ladies. She found that they were by no means so well-bred as they had seemed at first, and that their manners were not so polished as she had expected. She was surprised, however, to find that they were very agreeable, and that they seemed to be in high spirits. As they entered the house, Elizabeth was struck by its grandeur and beauty. The hall was large and lofty, with a handsome staircase, and the rooms were all well-furnished and elegantly decorated. She was delighted with the library, which was well-stocked with books, and the music-room, which was fitted up with every necessary instrument. As they passed through the house, Elizabeth could not help but feel a sense of awe at the grandeur of the establishment. She had never seen anything like it before, and she was amazed at the wealth and luxury that surrounded her. She was also struck by the number of servants, who seemed to be everywhere, and the ease with which they moved about the house. As they reached the drawing-room, Elizabeth was greeted by Mr. Bingley, who was standing by the fire, and who came forward to welcome her. He was as agreeable as ever, and Elizabeth was delighted to see him. She was also pleased to see that he seemed to be in high spirits, and that he was as attentive to her as ever. As they sat down to dinner, Elizabeth could not help but feel a sense of comfort and ease. She was surrounded by people who seemed to be friendly and agreeable, and she was enjoying herself immensely. She was also pleased to see that her sister was getting on well with Mr. Bingley's sisters, and that they seemed to be hitting it off. As the evening wore on, Elizabeth found herself feeling more and more at home, and she was grateful to her sister for having brought her to Netherfield. She was also grateful to Mr. Bingley for his hospitality, and for the trouble he had taken to make her feel welcome. As the night drew to a close, Elizabeth retired to her room, feeling happy and content. La señora Bennet no podía dejar de pensar en las posibilidades que esto ofrecía para sus hijas, y se puso a imaginar cómo podría ser la vida de una de ellas como la señora de Netherfield. Mientras tanto, las hermanas Bennet estaban ansiosas por conocer al señor Bingley y ver si era tan agradable como parecía. La expectación en la casa de los Bennet era palpable, y todos estaban ansiosos por ver qué sucedería a continuación.

Elizabeth's colour rose again, but she replied with a smile, "I was merely glancing over it, and had not formed any opinion, but I should be happy to hear yours." Mr. Darcy smiled, and began to discuss the book, and Elizabeth found herself listening with interest, and even pleasure. en_first_half: “I do not see what right Mr. Darcy had to decide on the propriety of his friend’s inclination; or why, upon his own judgment alone, he was to determine and direct in what manner that friend
en_second_half: was to be happy. But,” she continued, recollecting herself, “as we know none of the particulars, it is not fair to condemn him. It is not to be supposed that there was much affection in the case.”
en_results_raw: should be allowed to make his own choice. It is not very likely that any sensible young woman would be rationally affected by a great house, a title, or a large fortune, in comparison of a fine, tall, handsome young man, with a pleasant countenance and a good understanding; and Mr. Darcy's pride would not even allow him to suppose that she could be so, whatever might be her reason for encouraging the attentions of his friend. He consoled himself with thinking, that his interference would be of little avail, and that it was rather the part of a prudent friend to dissuade him from such a match, than to encourage him to make a choice which might lead to his own unhappiness. But still he could not help feeling, that he had done something to prevent the marriage, and that he had been the means of separating two people who were very well suited to each other, and who would have been happy together. He could not help thinking, that if he had not interfered, they would have been married by this time, and that he would have been spared the pain of seeing his friend so unhappy. He was also conscious, that he had been guilty of a great deal of pride and haughtiness, in his behaviour to Elizabeth, and that he had not treated her with the respect and kindness which she deserved. He was afraid, that he had lost her esteem, and that she would never be able to forgive him for his conduct. These thoughts tormented him, and he could not help feeling, that he had acted very wrong in endeavouring to prevent the marriage, and that he had been the cause of his friend's unhappiness.

But I think he is still a very agreeable man, and I am glad that Jane is so fond of him." Just then, the door opened, and Mr. Bingley himself came in, looking very pleased and self-satisfied. "Well, my dear sisters," he said, "I have just had the most delightful news. I have been to see the lawyer, and he tells me that everything is settled, and that I am free to marry whenever I please. I am thinking of having the wedding in the summer, as soon as the weather is warm enough. What do you think, my dear Jane? Would you like to be married in the summer?" Jane blushed and looked down, but Elizabeth could see that she was pleased. "I think it would be very nice," she said, "but I do not know whether it would be convenient. We must talk it over and see what can be done." "I am sure it will be all right," said Mr. Bingley, "I will see to everything. I will make all the arrangements, and you shall have nothing to do but enjoy yourselves. I promise you, it will be a very happy day." Elizabeth could not help but feel a little annoyed at Mr. Bingley's self-satisfaction, but she said nothing, and the conversation turned to other subjects.

tr_results_raw: karşılığında görmeye ihtiyacım yok. Seni sevdiğim için seni seviyorum ve bu bana yetiyor. Lady Catherine'in davranışları, seni bana daha da yakınlaştırdı. Artık onunla ilgili tüm endişelerim ortadan kalktı. Seninle birlikte olmak, bana mutluluğun ne demek olduğunu öğretti. Seni her geçen gün daha da çok seviyorum ve bu his, beni her şeye karşı daha güçlü kılıyor.
